content.title: Recurrent Carotid Stenosis

definition.primary: Hemodynamically significant stenosis (≥50%) occurring at the site of prior carotid intervention (endarterectomy or stenting), caused by neointimal hyperplasia (early recurrence) or progression of atherosclerosis (late recurrence).
key_concepts: Early recurrence (< 2 years) typically due to myointimal hyperplasia
Late recurrence (> 2 years) usually represents new atherosclerosis
Management differs from de novo carotid stenosis

early_recurrence.histology: Smooth muscle cell proliferation with extracellular matrix deposition
characteristics: Less prone to embolization than atherosclerotic plaque
May stabilize or regress over time

late_recurrence.histology: Typical atherosclerotic plaque with lipid core, necrosis, inflammation
characteristics: Similar embolic potential to primary atherosclerosis

post_cea.incidence: 5-22% depending on definition and follow-up duration

post_cas.in_stent_restenosis: More common than post-CEA recurrence in some series

considerations: Myointimal hyperplasia less likely to cause symptoms than atherosclerotic recurrence

post_cea: Duplex at 1 month, 6 months, then annually for 5 years
Beyond 5 years: individualized based on findings
post_cas: Duplex at 1 month, 6 months, then annually

imaging.utility: Primary surveillance tool, may be affected by stent artifact
imaging.criteria: PSV > 125-150 cm/s suggests ≥ 50% stenosis (may need stent-specific criteria)

imaging.utility: Alternative when CT contraindicated, no stent artifact with TOF technique
Gold standard, reserved for equivocal cases or planned intervention

asymptomatic_recurrence.rationale: Lower stroke risk than de novo stenosis, especially with myointimal hyperplasia

treatment_options.challenges: Scarring, cranial nerve injury risk, may require patch angioplasty

stroke_risk.asymptomatic_recurrence: 1-2% annual stroke risk (lower than primary stenosis)
stroke_risk.symptomatic_recurrence: Higher risk, similar to symptomatic primary stenosis

intervention_outcomes.repeat_intervention: Higher complication rates than primary procedures

surgical_technique: Patch closure reduces early recurrence vs primary closure
Eversion endarterectomy may have lower recurrence than conventional

content.statement: Recurrent Carotid Stenosis is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Carotid that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Recurrent Carotid Stenosis.

learning_objectives: Apply appropriate surveillance protocols post-CEA and post-CAS
Select optimal treatment strategy based on prior intervention and anatomy
key_points: Early recurrence is usually myointimal hyperplasia, late is atherosclerosis
Myointimal hyperplasia has lower embolic potential than atherosclerosis
Patch closure at CEA reduces recurrence compared to primary closure
CAS is preferred for post-CEA recurrence (avoids hostile neck)
clinical_pearls: Duplex velocity criteria may differ for stented vs non-stented arteries
Consider CAS for post-CEA recurrence to avoid scarred surgical field
Surgical stent removal may be needed for recurrent in-stent restenosis
Aggressive medical therapy reduces late atherosclerotic recurrence
